awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  High-Performance Perovskite Solar Cells Enabled by Layer-Specific Photonic Treatment and Incorporation of a Functional Polymer
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to greatly advance photovoltaics (materials for solar cells) made with special materials called perovskites, and enable high-speed printing of these solar cells on flexible underlying structures, known as substrates.  This would enable large-volume manufacturing of these flexible solar cells for many applications.  For instance, a freight truck trailer or refrigerated van covered by high-efficiency, lightweight and flexible solar panels would generate sufficient electricity to power all units on board, significantly reducing diesel fuel consumption and avoiding idle run during rest stops.  Another potential use is retrofitting shading fabrics, such as those used on carports; this would not only effectively block sunlight and thus minimize car heating, but could also supply additional power for lighting and/or charging electric vehicles. This could also be used for forward operating bases or other remote military operations if integrated with tents, reducing diesel fuel demand and the associated risk to the supplying troops, as well as associated costs. 

The proposed project will develop a technology to enable large-scale manufacturing of high-performance fully-flexible perovskite solar cells. In spite of rapid progress in efficiency and low-cost potential from solution processing capability, perovskite solar cells still have to overcome a few obstacles before becoming economically competitive in the photovoltaic market. In particular, life span and the lengthy annealing time limit the capability for high-speed printing. The proposed technology innovation will address these two main issues through a novel process and material engineering. In this PFI-TT project, photonic irradiation will be utilized to achieve rapid layer-specific annealing for the metal oxide charge transport layers without damaging the underlying flexible substrate and perovskite absorber layer. The high-quality metal oxide films will not only improve solar cell stability by providing physical protection to the perovskite active layer, but also maintain the efficient charge transport and efficiency, achieving the best of both worlds. In addition, a particular polymer will be added into the perovskite precursor solution to form ultra-smooth and stable perovskite films. With the proposed rapid and layer-specific annealing and incorporation of a particular dendrimer in the perovskite absorber layer, highly-stable perovskite solar cells with efficiency above 20% on flexible substrates will be accomplished.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we demonstrated high-performance perovskite solar cells (PSCs) with rapid photonic annealing of all stacking layers, enabled by ultraviolet (UV) light-emitting diode (LED) sources, to replace lengthy and energy-intensive thermal annealing. The UV-LED annealing technique allows for layer-specific annealing, where the selected light source provides a precise UV wavelength for maximizing the amount of light absorption by the target layer. The disparity in optical absorption between the target layer and the underlying films allows the stack of the underlying films to remain relatively unaffected, making this process ideal for heating sensitive substrates.  Along with a systematic investigation into the layer-specific annealing mechanism, our results demonstrate that this UV-LED-based photonic annealing method can produce PSCs with the power conversion efficiency (PCE) of over 23%, the highest reported among optically annealed PSCs. Moreover, the PSCs fabricated with UV-LED annealing demonstrated significantly improved stability as compared to the control devices with lengthy thermal annealing. These findings represent significant strides toward achieving rapid, cost-effective, and scalable manufacturing of commercial perovskite-based photovoltaics. In addition, polyamidoamine (PAMAM) dendrimer is employed to enhance the efficiency and stability of the double cation-based PSCs via different fabrication scenarios. Based on our experimental results and numerical analysis, application of a thin layer of PAMAM macromolecules at the interface of the perovskite absorber and the hole transport layer gives rise to enhanced performance, including both efficiency and stability, due to reduced interface defects and lower carrier recombination. The results suggest that PAMAM as a capping layer can effectively passivate the surface defects of the perovskite film. This research could significantly impact the field by providing valuable insights on surface passivation using macromolecules to improve performance of perovskite-based photovoltaic devices.

Based on current technology advancement, the main obstacle to the commercialization of perovskite-based photovoltaics is their instability and limited lifespan. In this PFI-TT project, we aim to address this challenge by developing a technology that enhances both stability and efficiency. During our customer discovery process, we found that the customer segments can be shifted towards portable solar generators. Instead of focusing on major solar energy markets such as building-integrated photovoltaics (BIPV), solar farms, and residential and community solar installations, where solar modules are exposed to harsh outdoor environments year-round, we are targeting applications where solar modules do not need to continuously operate in such conditions. In a portable solar generator, solar modules and power electronics are separate, allowing for plug-and-play use. If low-cost, high-efficiency perovskite solar modules can last for approximately three to five years, similar to the warranty period of batteries and microinverters, manufacturers of portable solar generators will adopt perovskite modules due to their lightweight nature, easy transportation, and comparable power production to the currently dominant silicon solar panels. In this setup, perovskite solar modules serve as the charging source for batteries, making the entire portable solar generator function like a rechargeable battery with a similar lifespan. When compared to diesel fuel generators, solar generators offer the benefits of quiet operation and the utilization of free sunlight as a fuel source. Overall, the proposed technology aims to overcome the instability and lifespan limitations of perovskite-based photovoltaics, while the pivot towards portable solar generators opens up new market opportunities that are more suitable for their unique characteristics.

As for accomplishments of technology commercialization and entrepreneurial education during project period, the PI and co-PI supervised students to conduct over 50 customer interviews. The PI and the postdoctoral research fellow formed a team and participated DoE American-Made Perovskite Startup Prize contests, during which we talked to experts in the field and learned much on commercialization of perovskite-based photovoltaics. Two graduate students had internship experience in solar industry setting, one in a startup, the other one in well-known solar company in USA. Moreover, the PI also participated multiple training and workshops on technology commercialization and entrepreneurship, such as IP-2-Market Program from Office of Innovation and Commercialization, Faculty/Staff Innovation Pitch Competition and won the first place in 2021 at The University of Alabama (UA). With partial support of this PFI-TT grant, two postdoctoral research fellows and four undergraduate researchers completed their research endeavor, and two graduate students continue their study to pursue PhD degree at UA. Also, one graduate-level course, ECE 693 Materials and Devices in Photovoltaics, has been developed and well accepted. Multiple research papers have been published in well-circulated journals, in which four undergraduate researchers are coauthors. The research results were also disseminated to communities by conference presentations and invited seminar talks.


Last Modified: 11/27/2024
Modified by: Dawen Li
